positive.review:
If you are new to the Drone/Quad/FPV hobby, this is not an "optional" purchase... It is your VERY VERY FIRST PURCHASE!!! I cannot stress this enough. If I had anyyyy cluuuuue jusst how simple everybody on youtube makes it look, to fly a quadcopter in all these different amazing ways - I could have saved myself nearly $2k that I spent on my initial purchase when I thought that I was "ready" to join the hobby... When in reality - I wouldd have never even thought about spending a dime more in the FPV/quad section of the RC world, if I had just listened to bardwell and everybody else, annd ONLY PURCHASED LIFTOFF & A DECENT ELRS RADIO that has BLE built in, FIRST!!!... All the youtuber's tell you to learn with sim, but I ignored that becausue I am not like most people when it comes to learning how to control any kind of vehicle. I have always been a easy & lightning fast learner in general, but especially when it comes to getting a feeling for new mechines & controlling them. I was 7 years old the first time I drove a car. it was a 1996 Ford Expedition, and the link between my brain and the vehicle was almost instanious. My own first car was a 5 speed stick shift - Got that down within 10 minutes of watching my uncle drive it in a parking lot from the passenger seat while he explained what he was doing/why... First time I rode a motorcycle, I lied to the owner and said I had owned one before - Literally rode it one way down the street to learn the clutch and shift pattern, turned around, and rode a wheelie past the owner on my 2nd pass not even 30 seconds later.... Later in life, I got in the drivers seat of a bobcat, and then an excavator and the exact same thing happened... I have ALWAYS been an absolute "natural" when it comes to learning the controls of any kind of mechanical object and almost instantly feeling as if I was "one with the machine" because the controls always feel like they're second nature to me, to the point where I have never needed to think about, or consciously calculate what my hands or feet are doing with the controls... They just do whats needed, 100% naturally without any thought, and without error...Ever, after being in one vehicle or another everyday for the past 20yrs now.... after I feel each of the controls, and undnerstand how they work, the attention/brainpower I have had to put into anyhting has always gone from 100% conscious thought, to 0% conscious & 100% SUBconscious, within minutes of learning in the real world... Mmy first nitro Traxxas RC Car?? Same exact thing there even... No matter what kind of mechanics I've thrown at myself, I have never struggled with the controls or getting a feeling for the machcine's limits.... UNTIL I TRIED TO FLY A QUAD... lol NOOOOBODY TELLS YOU HOW SIMPLE THEY MAKE FLYING DRONES LOOK ON YOUTUBE, COMPARED TO HOW MUCH ACTUAL TIME THEY'VE HAD TO SPEND LEARNING TO FLY AS WELL AS THEY DO... They all say to put 10 hours into the simulator first. but that's about all they ever say... Had I listened and thought that wouldnt appply to me - I 100% would have never spent a dime pastpaying for liftoff & my radio. I would have nevvvver considered trying to learn how to fly a quad-rotor after my first hour in liftoff... I am now, currently almost 3 years & over 100hrs into the sim, and STILL have not put my BNF drone I made the mistake of purchasing, in the air, in real life, other than just to hover around and make sure that it worked for less than 1 pack.

That "One with the machine" type of feeling when you are flying a drone,
Take it from somebody who bought everything in one shopping cart for almost $2,000USD and literally NONE of it has been used/is all outdated now... If you want to get into this hobby, The one and only thing you should spepnd any moneye on before anything else is Liftoff and a radio.. 100-200 USD total... DO NOT SPEND A DIME ON ANYTHING ELSE UNTIL YOU SPEND AT LEAST 10HRS IN LIFTOFF, TO KNOW WHETHER YOU HAVE THE SPARE TIME & PATIENCE TO FULLY LEARN TO FLY, AND COMMIT YOURSELF TO IT... Because had I know just how simple they make it look on youtube, compared to how hard it actually is to do in the sim, and in real life - for me, personally, for whatever reason - I would have never purchased anything further. I love everything about FPV and the ehobby aspect of it. I really don't care for the actual flying part though. something about it has still just never fully "clicked" for me. 

Everybody learns different things in different ways. Don;t make the same mistakes I did. I have 100+ hours into this simulator and am just barely confident enough to spin my real life motors up and put my  real $600 drone in the air. STILL. lol getting into this hobby in real life requires TONS of extra, real life money, and the time to spend in real life YEARS of flying daily in order to ever aquire that "subconscious, one with machine" type fo feeling over any drone. KNOW THIS, AND HEED MY WARNING!!!
Surprisingly, the simulator is exceptional in duplicating the flights i've taken in my Avata 2. Great simulator,  great trainer, great game!!!
Great game. Started here with flying FPV. After some time in the game I flew my 5inch drone with no problems. Skills transfer over pretty well minus a few things like wind.
Very fun and realistic with lots of fun maps and drones to fly
Fairly realistic physics and decent visuals.It works ok to practice manual FPV but it really needs an easy way to hook-up goggles to get the best FPV practice.  I score Liftoff 70/100.

TLDR: Very good and polished learning environment with a plethora of maps that have ample room for diverse challenges and let's you grow beyond the basics. Once you can somewhat fly it's also really fun. 

(For me the tutorials were a bit hard in the beginning. I went to an open map instead to fly very wide manoeuvers and get a feel for the drone first. I then gradually increased the difficulty. That helped a lot and was less frustrating.)

Very fun sim to learn to fly. 10/10.

Wish for more fun maps!

Most fun quadcopter sim by far. 

The levels are well designed and fun. Some of them, like Surtur and Hannover, are huge. And there's tons of third party content and possibilities with the track editor.

The physics are realistic enough-and they're beta testing a new implementation right now. The game has an extensive customization system for putting together your own drones, from realistic components.

It runs comparatively well on lower end GPUs. Some of the other sims have more realistic looking graphics but tend to feel more bland to me. Liftoff's level design feels more intentional.

Another great thing, for advanced simulation, that other sims (AFAIK) lack is the telemetry output. You can have it send various real-time information about the drone to external applications for display and analysis.
Great game for beginners and learning the basics
My favorite and most-played in the drone flight sim genre - recognizes all my transmitters.
a very good game with realistic physics and it helped fly my dji avata 2 in manual mode so i suggest this game also you should get slip stream and dji dlc i was not given this game for free
Liftoff is the only game where I can crash $500 worth of drone parts without actually crying in real life. 10/10 would lawn-dart into a virtual tree again.
Good starter, but the physics feel far too floaty compared to when I fly my 5" IRL. Good content and decent graphics, physics are just not very good compared to competitors like Velocidrone (#1)

However, I am still uncertain as to whether superior computing would result in a tiny performance enhancement, not noticeable, but giving it that little something extra and becoming playable. I can hardly fly the thing on most of the courses. The frame rate is more than adequate. But the aircraft goes too fast most of the time and the controls cannot keep up. Now I'm going to try it on ubuntu.

The short of it is I've learned FPV drone flight in ACRO within this sim and have been able to transfer it even over to another sim as well. The tutorial was very helpful after going to a Freeflight stage and practicing what I learned of the basics then returning to it so more tutorials or even a longer tutorial that guides users into advance flight (different stick positions for what) would be welcomed probably by others as well. Fun, real feel and graphics are nice.

i love the wide variety of drones, and i absolutely love using the DJI FPV! ive been training for real world FPV and the amount of skills ive learned playing this game are un-countable! just one thing i dislike, the DJI FPV doesn't have RTH or the N mode obstacle avoidance... and i dont have a dji FPV controller, so if you need one for RTH then the DJI FPV drone is not as realistic as the IRL drone. oh! cant forget, the DJI FPV also doesn't have break. so if i get into a pickle in manuel mode, short answer, the drone will not be having a good day.

Highly recommend!
Liftoff is such a great simulator. It really helps you get the feel of FPV before flying a real drone. The physics are super realistic, and it's perfect for practicing control and confidence without worrying about crashing an actual quad. Totally worth it if you're starting FPV!
great game, i would love more big nature maps

Realistic, fun and has many map options to choose from. I recommend to try it, especially if you have an FPV controller.
It is the most realistic. If you think IRL ones are weaker, just choose a weak drone in this simulator.

Liftoff nails the feel of FPV flight. Controls are tight, physics behave like a real quad, and the community-made tracks keep sessions interesting. Requires a radio/controller, setup is straightforward and the game maps cleanly to hobby transmitters; the RadioMaster Pocket works brilliantly and makes flying immediate and precise. Good for beginners learning stick control and deep enough for sim pilots who want to tune PID and rates. Minimal friction to get into multiplayer races or freestyle sessions. Buy if you want a realistic FPV simulator without risking your real quad.

So one night as I was doom scrolling I saw a short of someone flying a drone and thought "I could do that"... which then led me to being at the "Buy now" button for an FPV drone when crossed my mind that crashing this thing could be expensive... which led to me doom scrolling reviews for a simulator where I came across one for Liftoff, and I decided that $20ish bucks is easier to spend if I crash. So I got out of bed, ran to my PC and bought and went back to bed while it was downloading. 

Fast forward to the next day when I discovered I can in fact NOT fly a drone... I did the training and found that near impossible, watched some more videos on how to fly and change some key settings so my Xbox controller works better for what I was trying to do. Then I just went into free fly mode and tried and tried tried... wasted thousands of dollars of drones in crashes but just hitting one button resets me. After about 5 hours I was doing some pretty decent maneuvers, and after 10 hours I was doing some much more complex moves and dodges around trees... granted I still can't do race track courses as that is just next level skill, and hats off to those that can. 

So that's how I learned that I can't fly a drone, but then learned... and am now waiting on $1800 worth of real drone equipment now and studying for my Basic drone Pilot certification test (ugh... Canada...). Yes I recommend if you want to try an FPV drone without the risk, and just like to cruise through some pretty good looking maps and maybe even if you have the skills to race.
Great for learning how to fly an fpv drone. I've tried several of the others. This is very well rounded.

Worst FPV simulator I have ever used. I dont understand why people like it or use it at all....
Spent 1.6 trying to setup controls and settings.

Trash training mode  buyer beware  yet another  waste of time and money  buy only if you know how to already fly.  not worth the frustration and trainig  modes sets you up for failure by not providing proper FMV from the start

Suggested improved controller support for expanding input options, devs immediately went on the defensive for implying their game could be improved. this game can only be fully enjoyed if you have or are willing to buy a real flight radio controller, controller support is negligible and seemingly not likely to ever be expanded or improved. if youre already into drone flying and or are willing ot buy the equipment needed to fully enjoy this game then you will likely enjoy it, but if youre newcomer to the hobby or dont think you'd be willing to buy extra equipment this is a hard pass.

tutorial sucks, pausing mid flight taking away control of the drone defeats the purpose of learning to fly if youre just gonna drop the controls as soon as your done with the pedantic instructions. "now provide some pitch, bring the right stick up slightly and keep it there" doesnt check if you have the stick in the correct orientation and just unfreezes the game. the turorial is an after thought to the simulator more of just an environment that at the ends asks you if you want to try again or move on.

Unable to changes controller settings/calibration without exiting the level/map and going back to the main menu.  This makes first setup on getting sensitivity/deadzones configured a chore.
As of this moment in time - do not recommend.

I have mixed feelings about this simulator.
As a complete beginner, I find it very unfriendly for newcomers. For people who already have months of flying experience, it‚Äôs probably great ‚Äî but like most FPV sims on Steam (Uncrashed, FPV.Skydive, etc.), it‚Äôs clearly made by pilots who already know how to fly and don‚Äôt think much about beginners.

The so-called ‚Äúflight tutorial‚Äù only covers a bit of theory and lacks any real flying lessons. There‚Äôs no actual flight school that tells you what you‚Äôre doing wrong or how to improve ‚Äî something that should really exist in 2025, especially with modern AI possibilities.

Suggestions for improvement:
Fix the painfully slow menu loading.
Include a few real beginners in the testing team.
Add exercises like from random movement - stop and hover in place.
Teach smooth throttle control.
Show a predicted flight path based on current stick inputs.
Add an error analyzer showing what the pilot does wrong and what the ideal stick positions would be.

This could become an amazing training tool - but right now, it feels more like it‚Äôs built for experienced pilots only.

As a total beginner, I can confirm that the simulator tutorial is not very beginner-friendly. I‚Äôve spent over 15 hours, and it‚Äôs still difficult to handle corners due to the lack of clear explanations.
For example: give slower drones, analyze what the user is doing wrong, and give the right directions. This is basic for all arts to learn. Use small steps and different practices. Split every tutorial you have into slower steps, remove boring writings, and put some love into the tutorial ‚Äî this is your main audience, I believe.

It might be fine for pros, but I believe most beginner pilots buy this app as their first flight teacher. And as a trainer, it leaves a lot to be desired.
I would recommend it as an overall simulator, but not for beginners ‚Äî at least from my personal experience.

I have mixed feelings about this simulator.
As a complete beginner, I find it very unfriendly for newcomers. For people who already have months of flying experience, it‚Äôs probably great ‚Äî but like most FPV sims on Steam (Uncrashed, FPV.Skydive, etc.), it‚Äôs clearly made by pilots who already know how to fly and don‚Äôt think much about beginners.

The so-called ‚Äúflight tutorial‚Äù only covers a bit of theory and lacks any real flying lessons. There‚Äôs no actual flight school that tells you what you‚Äôre doing wrong or how to improve ‚Äî something that should really exist in 2025, especially with modern AI possibilities.

Suggestions for improvement:
Fix the painfully slow menu loading.
Include a few real beginners in the testing team.
Add exercises like from random movement - stop and hover in place.
Teach smooth throttle control.
Show a predicted flight path based on current stick inputs.
Add an error analyzer showing what the pilot does wrong and what the ideal stick positions would be.

This could become an amazing training tool - but right now, it feels more like it‚Äôs built for experienced pilots only.

As a total beginner, I can confirm that the simulator tutorial is not very beginner-friendly. I‚Äôve spent over 15 hours, and it‚Äôs still difficult to handle corners due to the lack of clear explanations.
For example: give slower drones, analyze what the user is doing wrong, and give the right directions. This is basic for all arts to learn. Use small steps and different practices. Split every tutorial you have into slower steps, remove boring writings, and put some love into the tutorial ‚Äî this is your main audience, I believe.

It might be fine for pros, but I believe most beginner pilots buy this app as their first flight teacher. And as a trainer, it leaves a lot to be desired.
I would recommend it as an overall simulator, but not for beginners ‚Äî at least from my personal experience.
